text.content: The output .svelte files make use of user-defined components to do the actual rendering. Let’s use a Notion “callout” as a simple example.

text.content: Or you could go crazy and have a callout that doubles as a toggle. Wat!? 🙀

text.plain_text: Or you could go crazy and have a callout that doubles as a toggle. Wat!? 🙀

text.content: Sure. You can add keyboard interactions, or make callouts behave according to user settings. Anything Svelte allows you to do, you can probably do it!

text.plain_text: Sure. You can add keyboard interactions, or make callouts behave according to user settings. Anything Svelte allows you to do, you can probably do it!

text.content: Here’s the code (blue border, with toggle)

text.plain_text: Here’s the code (blue border, with toggle)

text.content:
(open = !open)}>
{emoji}
{#if open}
{:else}
⟩
{/if}

text.content: Don’t worry. You don’t need to explicitly remember this location. You’ll get a standard Svelte error if you try to run your app without the necessary components in place. After all, they’re just regular Svelte imports. Nothing special.
